questions.text: which type of signalling is shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
In the image- one cell is secreting the hormone and the other cell Nearby or Neighbour Cell have a receptor for that hormone, this signalling takes place without passing through the bloodstream. Hence, it is paracrine.

Paracrine Signalling is defined as in which a hormone acts on nearby cells without ever passing through the systemic Circulation.

questions.text: which of the following will cause a decrease in extra cellular K+?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine binds to Na+/K+ pump. It is known to cause Hypokalemia by binding to beta receptor.

Acidemia causes K+ to come out of the cell, thereby increasing its Extracellular Level.

Glucagon has been shown to increase plasma K+ effect opposite to insulin.

Atropine has been shown to raise Plasma K+.

questions.text: Which of the following will be involved in baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
The baroreceptor reflex is a negative feedback mechanism that helps maintain blood pressure homeostasis. When blood pressure rises, baroreceptors (in the carotid sinus and aortic arch) send signals to the medulla, leading to decreased sympathetic output and increased parasympathetic activity, reducing heart rate and vasodilation to lower blood pressure. Conversely, if blood pressure drops, the reflex increases sympathetic activity to restore normal levels.

Incorrect Options:

  • B) Positive Feedback: Enhances or amplifies a response, which is not suitable for blood pressure regulation (e.g., childbirth contractions via oxytocin).
  • C) Adaptive Feedback: Adjusts to long-term changes but is not the immediate mechanism of the baroreceptor reflex.
  • D) Feed Forward: Anticipates changes before they occur (e.g., heart rate increase before exercise) but is not the primary mechanism of baroreceptors.

Key Takeaways:

  • Baroreceptor reflex = Negative feedback mechanism for BP regulation.
  • Works by adjusting autonomic nervous system activity.
  • Prevents excessive BP fluctuations, ensuring cardiovascular stability.

choices.text: Dotted lines represent pressure with no micturition
Segment 1A denotes pressure due to residual urine
Micturition reflex is inhibited at phase 2

questions.text: True about following figure?
questions.solution:
The Image is a Cystometrogram.

Segment 1a represents a slight rise in pressure when the first increment in volume is produced.

Segment 1b long and Nearby Flat Segment as further increments are produced and is a true reflection of Laplace Law. It shows plasticity of bladder

Segment II - A sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered.

Dotted lines represent micturition reflex.

C fibres are more susceptible to pressure to A fibres

questions.text: Which of the following event occur during phase B to rise body temperature to hypothalamus set point?
questions.solution:
The anterior hypothalamus compares the detected core temperature to the set-point temperature.

  • If the core temperature is below the set point, heat-generating mechanisms (e.g., increased metabolism, shivering, vasoconstriction of cutaneous blood vessels) are activated by the posterior hypothalamus.
  • If the core temperature is above the set point, mechanisms for heat loss (e.g., vasodilation of the cutaneous blood vessels, increased sympathetic outflow to the sweat glands) are activated by the anterior hypothalamus.

questions.text: Which nucleus is involved in hemiballismus?
questions.solution:
Hemiballismus: Sudden, wild flailing of one side of the body

Caused by lesion to contralateral subthalamic nucleus (eg, due to lacunar stroke) In hemiballismus, half-of-body is going ballistic

Option a) globus pallidus - involvement leads to athetosis

Option b) caudate nucleus- involvement leads to chorea

Option c) substantia nigra: involvement leads to Parkinson's disease
